com.martinambrus.adminAnything

Class Utils

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.martinambrus.adminAnything.Utils

  • public final class Utils
extends java.lang.Object
    Various common utilities class used thorough the whole AA plugin.

    • Method Detail

      • getUnixTimestamp

        public static int getUnixTimestamp()
        Returns current unix timestamp.

        Example: 
         // ... as used in /aa_mutecommand ...
 // check if this class should still be muted
 if ((mutedClasses.get(newMutedClass) + maxMuteCheckTimeout) > Utils.getUnixTimestamp()) {
     lastClassMuted = true;
 }
        Returns:
        Returns current unix timestamp as an Integer.

      • getUnixTimestamp

        public static int getUnixTimestamp(java.lang.Long i)
        Converts given timestamp in milliseconds to Unix Timestamp in seconds.

        Example: 
         // ... as used in the commandPreprocessor event listener ...
 Aa_mutecommand.lastMuteTimestamp = Utils.getUnixTimestamp(0L);
        Parameters:
        i - Integer timestamp in milliseconds to convert.
        Returns:
        Returns Unix Timestamp in seconds.

      • getMinecraftVersion

        public static java.lang.String getMinecraftVersion()
        Grabs the numerical version portion of the full server's version.

        Example: 
         String serverVersion = Utils.getMinecraftVersion();
        Returns:
        Returns server version as a string (for example "1.11.2").

      • getMinecraftVersion

        public static java.lang.String getMinecraftVersion(java.lang.String serverVersion)
        Grabs the numerical version portion of the full server's version.

        Example: 
         Utils.getMinecraftVersion(Bukkit.getServer().getBukkitVersion());
        Parameters:
        serverVersion - An optional version string to extract the version from.
        Returns:
        Returns server version as a string (for example "1.11.2").

      • supportsJsonChat

        public static boolean supportsJsonChat()
        Checks whether the server supports extended JSON chat formatting (with links, commands, hovers etc.)

        Example: 
         // as used in numerous places where the chat-GUI is involved
 if (this.sender instanceof Player && Utils.supportsJsonChat()) {
   // do some fancy schmancy chat magic
 }
        Returns:
        Returns true if JSON chat is supported by the server version, false otherwise.

      • flatten

        public static java.lang.String flatten(java.util.List<java.lang.String> l,
                       boolean... addCommas)
        Returns a flat version of a list, similarly to how .toString() does it.

        Example: 
         ArrayList cmds = new ArrayList();
 cmds.add("ban");
 cmds.add("say");
 cmds.add("pardon");

 // prints out: "you have requested to disable the following commands: ban, say, pardon"
 System.out.println("you have requested to disable the following commands: " + Utils.flatten(cmds, true));
        Parameters:
        l - The list to convert into a string.
        addCommas - If this parameter is set, commas will be used to join list elements together.
        Returns:
        Returns a comma-separated list of values from the String List given.

      • flatten

        public static java.lang.String flatten(java.util.Set<java.lang.String> l,
                       boolean... addCommas)
        Returns a flat version of a set, similarly to how .toString() does it.

        Example: 
         HashSet cmds = new HashSet();
 cmds.add("ban");
 cmds.add("say");
 cmds.add("pardon");

 // prints out: "you have requested to disable the following commands: ban, say, pardon"
 System.out.println("you have requested to disable the following commands: " + Utils.flatten(cmds, true));
        Parameters:
        l - The set to convert into a string.
        addCommas - If this parameter is set, commas will be used to join set elements together.
        Returns:
        Returns a comma-separated list of values from the String Set given.

      • flatten

        public static java.lang.String flatten(java.lang.String[] l,
                       boolean... addCommas)
        Returns a flat version of an array, similarly to how .toString() does it.

        Example: 
         String[] cmds = new String[3];
 cmds[0] = "ban";
 cmds[1] = "say";
 cmds[2] = "pardon";

 // prints out: "you have requested to disable the following commands: ban, say, pardon"
 System.out.println("you have requested to disable the following commands: " + Utils.flatten(cmds, true));
        Parameters:
        l - The array to convert into a string.
        addCommas - If this parameter is set, commas will be used to join array elements together.
        Returns:
        Returns a comma-separated list of values from the String[] array given.

      • flatten

        public static java.lang.String flatten(java.lang.String[] l,
                       java.lang.String delimiter)
        Returns a flat version of an array, similarly to how .toString() does it. This method signature allows for choosing your own delimiter.

        Example: 
         String[] cmds = new String[2];
 cmds[0] = "minecraft";
 cmds[1] = "ban";

 // prints out: "the plugin command was minecraft:ban"
 System.out.println("the plugin command was " + Utils.flatten(cmds, ":"));
        Parameters:
        l - The array to convert into a string.
        delimiter - The actual delimiter to use when joining array elements together.
        Returns:
        Returns a delimiter-separated list of values from the String[] array given.

      • makeListMutable

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> makeListMutable(java.util.List<java.lang.String> theList)
        Takes an unmodifiable list and turns it into a modifiable one.
        Parameters:
        theList - The list we want to clone and make modifiable.
        Returns:
        Returns an ordinary cloned, modifiable list.

      • compactQuotedArgs

        public static java.lang.String[] compactQuotedArgs(java.lang.String[] args)
        Takes command arguments that may contain quotes and will compact them, so for example "hello dolly" will become a single argument.

        Example: 
         String[] args = new String[3];
 args[0] = "command";
 args[1] = "\"hello";
 args[2] = "dolly\"";

 // newArgs will be: ["command", "\"hello dolly\""]
 String[] newArgs = Utils.compactQuotedArgs(args);
        Parameters:
        args - A String[] array with all of the command's arguments.
        Returns:
        Returns a String[] array with quoted original arguments consolidated and the rest untouched.

      • logDebug

        public static void logDebug(java.lang.String msg,
            AdminAnything aa)
        Logs a debug message into the console if debug is enabled in AdminAnything.
        Parameters:
        msg - The message to log.
        aa - Instance of AdminAnything.

      • shortenStringArray

        public static java.lang.String[] shortenStringArray(java.lang.String[] orig,
                                    java.lang.Integer len)
        Copies the original array into a new array, shortening it to the given length. Copy will start at index 0.

        Example: 
         String[] cmds = new String[3];
 cmds[0] = "ban";
 cmds[1] = "say";
 cmds[2] = "pardon";

 // cmds2 will be ["ban", "say"]
 String[] cmds2 = Utils.shortenStringArray(cmds, 2);
        Parameters:
        orig - Original array to copy from.
        len - Length to which we want to shorten the original array.
        Returns:
        Returns a shortened version of the original array.

      • CheckParentesis

        public static boolean CheckParentesis(java.lang.String str)
        Checks whether the given string has a matching set of parenthesis (for our purposes, brackets only).

        Example: 
         // as used in the Permissions class
 String query = "(I open but I won't close";

 if (!Utils.CheckParentesis(query)) {
   Bukkit.getLogger().severe("[AdminAnything] Invalid permissions query check passed to the checkPerms() method: " + query);
   return false;
 }
        Parameters:
        str - The actual query string to count matching brackets for.
        Returns:
        Returns true if the given query string has a matching number of brackets, false otherwise.
